div1.p: Carr gives an autopsy report on yellow fever victim Robert Sherman.

div1.head: Autopsy on the Body of a Man Known as Robert Sherman, American, Engineer, Home Stated by Himself to be in Nevada, Who Died in the Hospital S. Izabel of a Fever, Diagnosed as Yellow Fever or “Febre Amareela”, by G. Jameson Carr, March 25, 1925

p.hi:
AUTOPSY ON THE BODY OF A MAN KNOWN AS ROBERT SHERMAN, AMERICAN, ENGINEER.
HOME STATED BY HIMSELF TO BE IN NEVADA, WHO DIED IN THE HOSPITAL S. IZABEL
OF A FEVER, DIAGNOSED AS YELLOW FEVER OR “FEBRE AMARELLA”.

div1.p:
The bed, on which the body lay, was stained in the centre
with a large patch, dark brown in colour, but with a few splatches of
bright red blood and was said by the attendant to have been urine
passed at death; the odour was that of urine.

I identified the body as that of Robert Sherman, whom I
had seen during life.
IDENTIFICATION MARKS. A complete double set of gold crowns in his mouth.

Left Hand:- An old healed linear scar stretching from the hypothenar
downwards and outwards over the thenar eminence for 4-1/2 centimetres.
A linear scar in front of and below the knuckle of the first finger
and a semi-circular scar over the knuckle of the second finger, both
about 2 cms. long.

On the anterior external surface of the upper third of the left fore-
arm there is an old tattoo of an American flag over an American eagle.
Scar of an old bubo in the left groin 3 cms. long. Scar of an old
healed ulcer in the upper third of the external surface of the penis,
and a recent scar on the dorsum of the prepuce.

APPEARANCE OF THE BODY:- The body shows marked post-mortem lividity
especially in the dependent parts with marked congestion of the face
and upper chest, the whole body being of a dirty occhre yellow colour,
most marked in the conjunctiva, face, upper chest and both sides of the
abdomen, but particularly marked round the region of the genitalia and
the anterior upper third of the thighs. There is oozing of a brown
fluid from the mouth and from the rectum a considerable quantity of
this brown fluid, but mixed with bright red blood. The mouth and
10.
25/3/25
posterior nasal passage contains a brown fluid.

An incision was made from the manubium sterni to the
symphysis pubis. The subcutaneous tissues and fat were of a canary
yellow. The muscles were pale and flabby but did not appear to be
stained yellow.

LUNGS:- Marked hypostasis in dependent parts, crepitant with apparently
ecohymotic hemorrhages scattered throughout of various sizes and
apparently of recent origin. They extended into the surface of the
lungs. This was more marked in the right lung, which was adherent,
latterly and superiorly to the parietal pleura. In the pleural
cavities of both lungs there was a quantity of dark brown fluid.

HEART:- In the state of diastole, the right heart containing post
mortem fluid blood. The myocardium was yellowish and of a dull lustre
but no eccymosis were seen. The endocardium, especially the papillary
muscles were distinctly yellow. There was a healed sortitis of the
first part of the aorta with calcareous plaques and calcareous re-
solution of vegetations on the aortic caarsps.

LIVER:- The liver was enlarged. The surface had marked yellow and
bluish mottling of fine design. On section very friable and a uniform
dirty yellow.

GALL BLADDER:- The gall bladder contained greenish bile and several
stones but no occlusion of the bile ducts or of the hepatic ducts.

KIDNEYS:- The kidneys were enlarged hyperaemic and of a yellowish
brown colour. Owing to the enormously thick capsule of fat, firmly
adherent to the true capsule of the kidney, it was shelled out
entire and with ease. On section, marked hyperrhaemia of the cortex,
especially at the junction of the cortex and medulla, while the
11.
25/3/25
medulla itself was stained yellow and in the pelvis was a mass of
bright yellow fat.

GASTRO-INTESTINAL SYSTEM:- The stomach and intestines were involved in
an enormous mass of bright yellow fat. The stomach itself contained
a dark green content, the serosa appeared normal, the sub-mucosa was
of a chocolate colour while the mucosa was minutely and intensely
injected with ecchymosis at the cardiac end. The small intestines
contained a similar fluid while the colon contents were more tarry
in nature.
BLADDER:- Full of dark brown urine.
SPLEEN:- Normal in appearance, no infarcts.

LYMPHATIC GLANDS:- Mesenteric and mediastinal were congested and some
had apparently hemorrhages. The serous membranes showed nothing in
particular. There were some ante-mortem patechial hemorrhages in
the skin.
